content.question: Two identical conducting spheres are mounted on insulating handles, as shown. Sphere <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> has a positive charge, and sphere <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> has no excess charge, as shown in Figure 1. Sphere <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is brought close to sphere <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, which is grounded with a wire, as shown in Figure 2. The grounding wire is disconnected and then sphere <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is removed, isolating sphere <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> as shown in Figure 3. Which of the following correctly predicts the charge on sphere <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> after this procedure is followed?

choices.label: Sphere <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will have a positive charge.
Sphere <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will have a negative charge.
Sphere <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will have no net charge.
Sphere <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will be polarized, and its left side will have a positive charge.
Sphere <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will be polarized, and its left side will have a negative charge.

content.answer: Sphere <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will have a negative charge.
